areaSubheader: The physical measure that defines size of the surface, one of the main properties of geometric shapes.
areaConcept: Intuitively, area can be perceived as a measure of how much space a certain object occupies relative to a plane. The concept of area is important in everyday life. It is applied everywhere: in geography, physics, architecture, engineering, construction, manufacturing, agriculture...
areaConditions: In planimetrics (two-dimensional geometry), any quantity that meets the following requirements can be defined as an area:
additive: additive (the area of the union of two non-overlapping shapees is equal to the sum of the areas of these two shapes);
congruent: congruent shapes (with the same size and form) have the same area;
squareOne: for a square with a side of 1, area is taken as 1
areaAxioms: Area can also be described using axioms, defining it as a set of certain plane shapes within the set of real numbers.
areaAnalogs: Area is the two-dimensional analogue of the length of a curve (one-dimensional concept) or the volume of a solid (three-dimensional concept).
areaMeasure: The units of measurement for area are square units. They can be gotten by replicating a linear unit of measurement along a perpendicular axis.
unitsSquare: Every unit of length has a corresponding unit of area, specifically the area of a square with the given side length.
si: In the International System of Units (SI), the basic unit of area is square meter (m²).
unitsRatio: Ratio between units is also squared. Therefore
trianglesInfo: A triangle is a geometric shape that consists of three points and three segments connecting them.
heightInfo: Any parallelogram can be divided in half by a diagonal, forming a triangle. Consequently, the area will also be divided in half. From this, we derive the formula <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>h</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>.
heightInfoTwo: Using trigonometric functions, another formula can be derived. The sine of the angle is the ratio of the opposite side to the hypotenuse <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>sin</mi><mfenced><mi>α</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>h</mi><mi>b</mi></mfrac></math>. From this, we get <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>sin</mi><mfenced><mi>α</mi></mfenced></math>. Substituting this into the first formula, we obtain <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>sin</mi><mfenced><mi>α</mi></mfenced></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>.
heightInfoThree: In an equilateral triangle, each angle equals 60°, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>sin</mi><mfenced><mrow><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. Using the height expressed through sine <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>sin</mi><mfenced><mrow><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>a</mi><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>, we can find that the ratio between the side and the height in such triangle is constant. Substituting this into the first formula, we acquire <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>a</mi><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>.
heightInfoFour: A right triangle is half of a rectangle divided by a diagonal; therefore, its area is also half of the rectangle's area. Hence, the formula <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>.
radiusInfo: If a circle is inscribed in scalene triangle by connecting the center of this circle with the points of tangency and the vertices, six smaller triangles are formed. By arranging them in a certain way, a rectangle with sides equal to the semiperimeter of the large triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>z</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>s</mi></math> and the radius of the inscribed circle can be formed. From this, we derive the formula <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>s</mi><mi>r</mi></math>.
quadrilateralsInfo: A quadrilateral (also known as quadrangle or tetragon) is a geometric shape that consists of four points and four segments connecting them.
squareInfo: A square is a quadrilateral with all sides equal and all angles right. According to the units of measurement of area, which are squares, its area is the square of its side <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.
rectangleInfo: A rectangle is a quadrilateral with all angles right, and opposite sides equal. From the formula for the area of a square, it is known that it is equal to the product of its sides. In a rectangle, adjacent sides are different, so the formula is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi></math>.
parallelogramInfo: A parallelogram is a quadrilateral with opposite sides equal and parallel. The side of a rectangle also serves as its height. A parallelogram, which is a skewed rectangle, has the same height but a different side. Hence, we get the formula <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>h</mi></math>.
parallelogramInfoTwo: Using trigonometric functions, another formula can be derived. The sine of the angle is the ratio of the opposite side to the hypotenuse <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>sin</mi><mfenced><mi>α</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>h</mi><mi>b</mi></mfrac></math>. From this, we get <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>sin</mi><mfenced><mi>α</mi></mfenced></math>. Substituting this into the first formula, we obtain <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>sin</mi><mfenced><mi>α</mi></mfenced></math>.
rhombusInfo: If we draw diagonals and create a new identical rhombus over the previous one, it is divided into four equal right triangles. By rotating them 180° relative to the midpoint of the hypotenuse, a rectangle with sides equal to the diagonals of the rhombus is formed. Hence, the area of the rhombus is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>.
hexagonInfo: By connecting the center of the hexagon with two angles of one side, a 60° angle is formed, which is a regular triangle. As known, there are six regular triangles in a regular hexagon, hence the formula <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mn>3</mn><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>.
ovalsInfo: An oval is a closed flat curve that is convex on all sides. There are many different types of ovals, but two most common are circle and ellipse.
circleInfo: A circle is a closed curve, all points of which are equidistant from one, which is the center of the circle. The part of the plane bounded by a circle is called a disk. If we divide the disk into equal sectors and then arrange them into a parallelogram, its side is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi></math> and its height is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>r</mi></math>. Substituting these values into the formula for the area of a parallelogram <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>h</mi></math>, we get <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.
sectorInfo: A sector is a part of a circle bounded by an arc and two radiuses connecting ends of the arc with the center of the circle. The angle of the arc is a certain part of the central angle, which in the case of a circle is 360°. By creating the ratio between the angles <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>°</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>360</mn><mo>°</mo></mrow></mfrac></math>, we also obtain the ratio between area of the sector and area of the circle. Therefore, the formula is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>°</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>360</mn><mo>°</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.
ellipseInfo: An ellipse is a plane curve surrounding two focal points, such that for all points on the curve, the sum of the two distances to the focal points is a constant. In the case of a circle, we multiply two perpendicular radiuses, which are equal. However, in an ellipse, there are the major and minor axes. Consequently, to find the area, we multiply them. Hence, the formula is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi></math>.
